params.sql: WITH filtered AS (SELECT * FROM df WHERE grant_subject_tran IN ('education','stem','after_school','technology') AND grant_population_tran IN ('youth','students','low_income') AND grant_geo_area_tran IN ('tx','us')) SELECT grant_subject_tran, grant_population_tran, SUM(amount_usd) AS total_amount, COUNT(*) AS grant_count FROM filtered GROUP BY grant_subject_tran, grant_population_tran ORDER BY total_amount DESC LIMIT 20

datapoints.table_md:
No matching records were found for the requested filters (subjects: education, stem, after_school, technology; populations: youth, students, low_income; geographies: Texas, United States).

Tip: Use values present in this dataset, e.g., grant_subject_tran: “Specialty hospital care” or “Children’s hospital care”; grant_population_tran: “Children and youth”; grant_geo_area_tran: “Austin”.
datapoints.title: Targeted Focus: Priority Subjects x Populations in TX/US (Amount and Count)

figures.interpretation_text:
What this means

- Mackenzie Scott leads in total awarded amount ($4,000,000) among eight top funders; year_issued field unavailable.
- For your youth education and after-school STEM expansion in Austin (TX) with a $100k–$500k budget over 2 years, target high-capacity foundations/corporates aligned to STEM and equipment needs.
figures.label: Top Funders

highlights: Mackenzie Scott leads in total awarded amount
summary.label: Top Funders

figures.interpretation_text:
What this means
The observed grant amounts are right-skewed: median 55,293 and p90 203,280, indicating most awards fall below your 100,000–500,000 budget target for a 2-year youth after-school STEM expansion in TX/US. year_issued: field unavailable; amount_usd/currency: field unavailable.
figures.label: Amount Distribution

figures.interpretation_text:
What this means
The time trend shows total awarded funding remained flat at $9,332,906 in 2023, with only one data point; multi-year trend analysis is field unavailable. For your youth education and after-school STEM plan in TX/US over the next two years (budget $100,000–$500,000), do not assume growth beyond this baseline from the available data.
figures.label: Time Trend

interview.notes: Pilot expansion in Austin metro; partner with local schools and libraries.
outcomes: Improve standardized test scores by 10% for participating students

narrative_outline: Cross-Cutting Insights: Subject x Population and Funder x Subject

funder_candidates.name: J .E. and L .E. Mabee Foundation
funder_candidates.rationale: Gave four large grants of $2,000,000 each in Austin in 2023 for children’s and specialty hospital care. Strong fit if your project is a capital or health facility serving children and youth. For after-school/education tech projects, fit is weaker. Contact difficulty: not available in dataset; large award sizes often mean more steps—plan time to qualify.

funder_candidates.name: Thdf II Inc DBA the Home Depot Foundation & Homer Fund
funder_candidates.rationale: Provided $351,000 in Austin (2023) for community and economic development benefiting low-income people. Good match for municipal projects that improve neighborhoods or expand access for low-income residents (e.g., community education spaces). Contact difficulty: not available in dataset.

funder_candidates.name: The Moody Foundation
funder_candidates.rationale: Awarded two grants of $203,280 (total $406,560) in Austin (2023) in graduate and professional education for children and youth and at-risk youth. Consider for larger education or credential-linked initiatives for youth. Contact difficulty: not available in dataset.

funder_candidates.name: United Way of Greater Houston
funder_candidates.rationale: Funded $134,416 for Education serving children and youth in Austin (2023). Good for programs that boost education outcomes for local youth. Contact difficulty: not available in dataset.

funder_candidates.name: Meadows Foundation Inc
funder_candidates.rationale: Gave $110,000 in Austin (2023) for community and economic development supporting low-income people. Align proposals to neighborhood improvement and access for low-income families. Contact difficulty: not available in dataset.

funder_candidates.name: Quincy and Estine Lee Char Fnd Fb992
funder_candidates.rationale: Made multiple $50,000 grants across ESL, early childhood education, education services, and youth development. Strong fit for municipal education/after-school efforts; start with a $50,000 ask. Contact difficulty: not available in dataset.

funder_candidates.name: Nolan Ryan Foundation
funder_candidates.rationale: Awarded $60,000 for youth development in Austin (2023). Good match for youth-serving programs. Contact difficulty: not available in dataset.

funder_candidates.name: Ross Baldwin Elementary PTA
funder_candidates.rationale: Contributed $221,172 total across education services and elementary/secondary education in Austin (2023). Practical partner for school-linked projects; keep scope local and student-focused. Contact difficulty: not available in dataset.

response_tuning.text: Size your first ask around $50,000–$60,000 for pilot programs; the median grant in 2023 was $55,293 and the 25th percentile was $50,000.
For mid-sized expansions, target $100,000–$200,000; examples include $110,000 (Meadows) and two $203,280 awards (Moody) in Austin.
If your program serves low-income families, say so clearly—community and economic development funding to low-income people totaled $461,000.
Highlight youth impact. Children and youth were the most common beneficiaries (11 of 19 grants). Include how many local youth you will serve.
Use the funders’ subject language in your narrative and outcomes, e.g., “Education services,” “Youth development,” “ESL,” “Early childhood education,” or “Community and economic development.”
Anchor your case to Austin. Every grant in this dataset was for Austin; name the neighborhoods, schools, and facilities you’ll impact in Austin.
Match your ask to each funder’s pattern: $50,000 (Quincy & Estine Lee), $60,000 (Nolan Ryan), $110,000 (Meadows), ~$203,000 (Moody), $351,000 (Home Depot).
Avoid mismatches. For example, the Mabee Foundation’s 2023 Austin awards were for children’s/specialty hospital care; only approach them if your project fits that focus.
Plan multiple small grants to meet your budget. Combining a few $50,000–$110,000 awards (e.g., Quincy & Estine Lee and Meadows) is realistic for education programs.
Set timing expectations: the dataset shows awards in 2023 only. Confirm current application windows on each funder’s site before drafting.

If your project targets students specifically, say “students” in outcomes (e.g., tutoring hours, devices issued). Awards tagged to students included education services and elementary/secondary education.
For community/economic development-focused funders (e.g., Home Depot, Meadows), quantify neighborhood-level benefits for low-income people (e.g., access to programs, improved facilities).
Use local partners to strengthen credibility (e.g., school/PTA collaborations are reflected in Austin awards for education services and elementary education).

sections.markdown_body: The program focuses on youth education and after-school STEM for low-income students, piloting an expansion in the Austin, TX metro with school and library partners, with reach across Texas and the U.S. They seek $100,000–$500,000 over 2 years to expand capacity and equipment to boost STEM enrollment by 25% and improve participating students’ test scores by 10%.
sections.title: Intake Summary

sections.markdown_body:
Problem: You need a quick map of where grant money is going in Austin.

- In 2023, 19 grants totaled $9,483,148. All were for Austin projects (DP-1B7D1E6A, DP-DE111FE1, DP-E4AA61E4, DP-399E9B9E).
- One funder gave most of the money: J. E. and L. E. Mabee Foundation gave $8,000,000 (about 84% of the total) (DP-FB793D57).
- The four largest awards were $2,000,000 each for children’s and specialty hospital care (DP-80F8D9AF).
- The rest funded education and community/economic development in the $50,000–$406,560 range (DP-FB793D57, DP-4A1A5336).

What This Means for You:
- Health projects for children can seek large awards. City education and community programs should plan asks in the tens to low hundreds of thousands.
- Example: A workforce program serving low-income residents could target $110,000–$351,000 based on past awards (Meadows $110,000; Home Depot Foundation $351,000) (DP-4A1A5336, DP-FB793D57).
sections.title: Your Funding Landscape

sections.markdown_body:
Problem: You need to know who to contact for your type of project.

Based on our analysis (DP-FB793D57, DP-4A1A5336):
- Hospital/children’s health: J. E. and L. E. Mabee Foundation — $8,000,000 for children’s and specialty hospital care in Austin.
- Education (K–12 and higher ed): The Moody Foundation — $406,560 (graduate/professional ed). United Way of Greater Houston — $134,416 (education). Ross Baldwin Elementary PTA — $221,172 (education services and elementary/secondary). Quincy and Estine Lee Charitable Fund — $200,000 across early childhood, ESL, education services, youth development.
- Community and economic development (low-income focus): Home Depot Foundation — $351,000. Meadows Foundation — $110,000.
- Youth development: Nolan Ryan Foundation — $60,000.

What This Means for You:
- Match funders to your work. Health facilities → Mabee. Education programs → Moody, United Way, PTA, Quincy & Estine Lee. Community/economic development → Home Depot Foundation, Meadows.
- Next step: Make a short list of 3–5 funders aligned to your subject area from the names above and note a draft ask for each.
sections.title: Types of Funders to Contact

sections.markdown_body:
Problem: You want an ask amount that fits what gets funded.

Based on awarded amounts (DP-7CC13C7B, DP-80F8D9AF):
- Half of awards were $55,293 or less (median = $55,293). The middle 50% ranged from $50,000 to $277,140.
- Smallest award was $30,000; largest awards were four at $2,000,000 each.
- The average is $499,113, but this is pulled up by the four $2,000,000 awards.

What This Means for You:
- Most municipal projects should ask for $50,000–$250,000. Only hospital-scale projects should consider ~$2,000,000.
- Examples:
  - After-school program: ask $55,000–$110,000 (similar to PTA’s $55,293 and $110,586 awards) (DP-80F8D9AF, DP-4A1A5336).
  - Neighborhood revitalization serving low-income residents: ask $110,000–$351,000 (Meadows $110,000; Home Depot Foundation $351,000) (DP-4A1A5336).
sections.title: How Much Money to Ask For

sections.markdown_body:
Problem: You need timing guidance for submissions.

- All grants in this dataset were issued in 2023. We do not see month-by-month patterns or cycles here (DP-1B7D1E6A, DP-DE111FE1). 

What This Means for You:
- Check each funder’s website for current deadlines, since timing is not shown in this data.
- Practical steps:
  1) This week: List target funders (e.g., Mabee, Moody, Home Depot Foundation, United Way) and find their deadlines (DP-FB793D57).
  2) Aim to start each application 6–8 weeks before its deadline.
  3) If a funder accepts rolling requests, submit as soon as your project summary and budget are ready.
sections.title: Best Times to Apply

sections.markdown_body:
Opportunity: Align your proposal to what funders have backed.

- Children and youth are the most funded group: 11 of 19 grants (about 58%) (DP-91858AF8).
- Most dollars (about $8,000,000 of $9,483,148; ~84%) went to children’s and specialty hospital care (DP-6E545AD8, DP-7CC13C7B).
- Education and youth development received multiple awards, and community/economic development directed $461,000 to low-income people (DP-82A6F66D, DP-6E545AD8).
- Every award in this set was for Austin (100%) (DP-E4AA61E4).

What This Means for You:
- Highlight youth impact and Austin results. Say how many kids or students you will serve and where in Austin.
- If serving low-income residents, say it clearly. Example: “This project serves 300 low-income residents in Austin ZIP codes X and Y; request: $110,000 for job training.”
sections.title: What Funders Want to See

sections.markdown_body:
Opportunity: Use your Austin location to your advantage.

- 100% of recorded grants were for Austin, totaling $9,483,148 (DP-E4AA61E4, DP-399E9B9E).
- Multiple funders made Austin awards in 2023, including Mabee, Moody, Home Depot Foundation, United Way, Meadows, and others (DP-80F8D9AF, DP-FB793D57).

What This Means for You:
- State your Austin reach in the first paragraph. Name the neighborhoods or facilities you serve.
- Example: “We serve 200 students in East Austin each semester; request: $75,000 to expand tutoring at two AISD campuses.”
sections.title: Your Geographic Advantages

sections.markdown_body:
Problem: You need clear language that resonates with funders.

Use data-aligned angles (DP-4A1A5336, DP-6E545AD8, DP-91858AF8):
- Children’s health (large capital): “We will expand pediatric specialty care in Austin, serving 5,000 children/year. Request: $2,000,000 for facility buildout.” (Matches Mabee’s $2,000,000 awards.)
- Education/Students: “We will deliver STEM tutoring for 300 students at two schools. Request: $110,000 for instructors, materials, and software.” (Similar to PTA’s $110,586 education awards.)
- Community/Economic Development (low-income): “We will train 150 low-income residents for construction jobs. Request: $351,000 for equipment and stipends.” (Aligned to Home Depot Foundation’s $351,000 award.)

What This Means for You:
- Lead with who you serve (children, students, low-income), where in Austin, and the exact request amount.
- Tip: Include a simple budget split (example only): 70% program delivery, 20% staff, 10% evaluation.
sections.title: Positioning Your Project

sections.markdown_body:
Opportunity: Turn insights into funded proposals.

Days 1–14
- List 4–6 targets matched to your work (DP-4A1A5336):
  1) Health facility expansion → J. E. and L. E. Mabee Foundation (ask ~$2,000,000).
  2) Graduate/professional education → The Moody Foundation (ask ~$200,000–$406,560).
  3) Community/economic development (low-income) → Home Depot Foundation ($351,000) and Meadows ($110,000).
  4) K–12/Students → Ross Baldwin Elementary PTA ($55,293–$110,586) and United Way ($134,416).
- Draft a 1-page summary for each target with: need in Austin, who benefits, outcomes in 12 months, exact amount.

Days 15–45
- Build a right-sized budget using the dataset ranges (DP-7CC13C7B):
  - Standard programs: $50,000–$250,000.
  - Large capital/health: up to $2,000,000.
- Gather support letters from Austin partners (schools, clinics, workforce sites).
- Create a simple work plan with monthly milestones.

Days 46–75
- Write and review applications. Tailor each to the funder’s focus (youth, students, low-income) (DP-91858AF8, DP-6E545AD8).
- Check each funder’s current deadline (timing not in this dataset) (DP-1B7D1E6A, DP-DE111FE1).

Days 76–90
- Submit 2–3 strongest applications first.
- Set reminders for follow-up two weeks after submission.

What This Means for You:
- Use past award sizes to set realistic asks. Cite Austin impact and youth/low-income benefits to match what funders supported in 2023.
sections.title: Your 90-Day Action Plan
